antonia

Obama said he was going to do this, so it is not surprising. I am glad he is living up to his promises. I disagree, however, with the U.K. article's description of Obama's order as contentious. What Bush did was contentious. Especially considering that the money was going through with the approval of the American people under Clinton, 65% of Americans support Roe, and a further percentage would adopt an even more radical posture on choice. Plus, it is good to know that impoverished and AIDS stricken nations, with devastating death rates, will finally be receiving financial assistance from our country instead of the empty and hypocritical, moral platitudes of religious fanatics. Totally out of touch with biological reality and the human suffering of 3rd world countries.
simone

.... It was a reassuring message that Mr. Obama takes seriously his duty to safeguard women's lives and basic rights, including free speech and the choice of whether to bear a child.
 
 The gag rule was first imposed by President Ronald Reagan. It barred any health care provider receiving American family planning assistance from counseling women on abortion, engaging in political speech on abortion or providing abortions, even with its own money.
 
 .... That seriously disrupted the best quality and most accessible family planning services in poor countries. It denied women access to desperately needed contraceptives, help in preventing H.I.V.-AIDS, and maternal care. Mr. Obama's executive order lifting the financing ban will mean fewer deaths from unsafe illegal abortions.
 
 Mr. Obama's stated intention to work with Congress to restore financing to the population fund also is a life-saving step. It ends the sorry exercise by which Mr. Bush repeatedly blocked money approved by Congress to advance poor women's reproductive health, reduce infant mortality, end sexual trafficking and prevent the spread of H.I.V. and AIDS.
 
 To justify this cruelty, the Bush administration perpetuated a bogus charge that the population fund has either stood by or helped with coerced abortions in China.

Not a federal government power as dictated in the constitution. The federal government has no business funding NPOs (the obvious exception of services performed for the federal government is ok but this is more a payment).

Wouldn't things be simpler if we all just followed the constitution???

 
 Let's see now.
 
 Would you be OK with the dissemination of kiddie porn at newsstands? After all, the First Amendment says "Congress shall make NO LAW abridging Freedom of the Press".
 
 Would you be OK with the abolition of "Stop and Frisk" laws? After all, the Fourth Amendment says that "No warrants shall issue except upon probable cause".
 
 Would you be OK with the state having to provide attorneys for each and every accused who could not afford one? After all, the Sixth Amendment says that "In all criminal prosecutions, the accused shall have the benefit of counsel for his defense."
 
 If so, OK; if not, I would be careful what I wished for were I you.

 No it wouldn't be simpler...it would be much much harder to remove your freedoms and to make social changes in the constitution/country. Having a king make all the decisions is easy...having a half dozen levels of government means it is hard to get something done which is the way the founders wanted it. Easiest for the local governments hardest for the federal.

Let's see now.
 
 Would you be OK with the dissemination of kiddie porn at newsstands? After all, the First Amendment says "Congress shall make NO LAW abridging Freedom of the Press".
 Doesn't say a state can't make the law.
 
 
Would you be OK with the state having to provide attorneys for each and every accused who could not afford one? After all, the Sixth Amendment says that "In all criminal prosecutions, the accused shall have the benefit of counsel for his defense."
It says nothing of paying for them. It just says you can't be denied a lawyer.
daewoo

Let's see now.
 
 Would you be OK with the dissemination of kiddie porn at newsstands? After all, the First Amendment says "Congress shall make NO LAW abridging Freedom of the Press".

 
 First, the states could still ban kiddie porn, and congress could still ban it in interstate commerce, and finally no right under the constitution has EVER been considered absolute. 
 

 Would you be OK with the abolition of "Stop and Frisk" laws? After all, the Fourth Amendment says that "No warrants shall issue except upon probable cause".

 
 Stop and frosk requires probably cause. 
 
 
Would you be OK with the state having to provide attorneys for each and every accused who could not afford one? After all, the Sixth Amendment says that "In all criminal prosecutions, the accused shall have the benefit of counsel for his defense."

 
 Actually, yes, I would. I think the system that most states use, where they will only provide an attorney if the accused faces jail time (or in some cases 30+ days of jail time) is wrong. For many people a $10,000 fine is worse than 90 days in jail. 
 
 We do not generally provide attorneys for free in this country. Typically the attorneys fees are tacked onto the fines and the accused ends up paying them...unless they are found not guilty, in which case the state pays them (which frankly makes sense to me). 
 
 If somebody wants a court appointed attorney for a speeding ticket, the court should appoint one. Of course the cost should be tacked on to their fine.
chester

It says nothing of paying for them. It just says you can't be denied a lawyer.

If the government does not provide federal funding for poorer women's access to abortion, they are not following the Constitution. Yes, it would be easier if they would. And easier if anti-choicers accept and recognize what has been established under our courts as Constitutional.
 
 

 
 Wrong on both counts. A poor woman has the right to pay for her own abortion just like anybody else. Not only does the constitution NOT require that the government provide such services for poor people, it takes a MAJOR exercise in twisted logic to argue it even ALLOWS it. Which of the powers of congress do you see as even allowing this.
 
 Nor did the supreme court find that abortion was constitutional. The Supreme court found that a federal law limiting abortion was unconstitutional. If an individual state were to pass the same law they would have an EXTREMELY strong constitutional argument in their favor. 
 
 We will never see that because the entire debate is perpetuate by extremists who are not happy unless that can force EVERYBODY to live up to their standards. Having some states allow abortion and some not is simply not good enough for them. Extremists care nothing for constitutional government unless it can be bent to their will.

Nor did the supreme court find that abortion was constitutional. 

 
 Hate to tell you this, fella, but ever since Roe V Wade, women have the right to choose. But if you work at McDonald's for minimum wage as a single parent with 3 kids and need to take time off to travel to the nether reaches of a state -- paying for hotel, transportation, childcare, time off from work, lost salary, the medical procedure itself -- you may very well not be able to exercise your right to choose. Duh.
 
 
We will never see that because the entire debate is perpetuate by extremists who are not happy unless that can force EVERYBODY to live up to their standards. 

 
 Like yourself? Now you are trying to imply that a simple Roe traditionalist is an extremist. Tut tut. Next, the gerbil from Chile will be on to call me a hairy communist.
 
 Really, I haven't seen anything so twisted since reading about the 1950's.

 So spare me your pretentious legal horse manure in the sky.

 Sorry, but you are simply WRONG. Frankly your first paragraph exposes the fact that you have no idea what is in our constitution.
 
 There is no "right to choose". There never has been, there never will be. It does not appear in the constitition, it does not appear in ANY state or federal law, it does not appear in ANY court ruling. The "right to choose" is a sound bite. No more, no less.
 
 What Roe did was prohibit the government from interfering in such a choice on the grounds that there is an implied right to privacy between a woman and her doctor. It was solely a decision that limited the actions of the federal government.
 
 Frankly the argument that you are putting forth, as well as being idiotic, would make a dman fine anti abortion argument. When Bush cut off that federal funding, they argued successfully in court that Roe was based on a perceived right to privacy between a woman and her doctor, but that in requesting that the federal government pay for the abortion, they are voluntarily breaching that privacy. 
 
 They court ruled in their favor on that as well as ruling that the government does not have any duty AT ALL to pay for any medical services for anybody. 
 
 I dont care about abortion one way or the other. I have advocated killing real, full grown people. I have advocated sticking little arab kids in thermal depolymerization units so we can pour them directly into our gas tanks...though I was half way kidding on that, I still think it might be a good idea for all those killed in Iraq. No sense in wasting all that meat.
 
 I cant decide if you are an extremist or just a fool. Would you argue that the constitution requires that the government pay for a poor woman to have a tooth pulled, or a heart transplant, or is it JUST abortions that we are for some reason you seem unable to explain or provide any precedent for required to pay for??
 
 On edit:
 
 Roe V Wade should be overthrown because it provides a pretty murky legal precedent that can be exploited for virtually anything. The Bush Administration cited Roe V Wade to keep from having to turn over documentation regarding authorization of torture. If you grant that there is a right to privacy between a woman and her doctor as a constitutional principal, it becomes impossible to argue that the same right does not exist between a gun owner and his gun smith, or virtually any other parties engaging in an activity that might be considered private. 
 
 It should be overturned and the issue left to the states. I expect that the vase majority of them will immediately pass laws allowing abortion. Some may not. It is called democracy.....
